conclusion: Two particles, A and B, are placed on the same horizontal plane and start moving in a straight line simultaneously from rest, from the same position, and in the same direction.
The v-t (velocity-time) graph of their motion is shown in the figure.

The image shows a velocity-time graph with two particles, A and B. Both start from rest and move in a straight line. Particle A has a linearly increasing velocity from 0 to 2v0 over time t0, followed by a linearly decreasing velocity back to 0 over 3t0. Particle B has a linearly increasing velocity from 0 to 2v0 over time t0, and then maintains a constant velocity 2v0 over 4t0, followed by a linearly decreasing velocity back to 0 over 5t0.

premise: The acceleration of a particle is determined by the slope of its velocity-time graph.
conclusion: During the deceleration phases, for particle A, the deceleration phase occurs from 2v0 to 0 over 3t0. The slope of this segment is -2v0/3t0.

premise: The acceleration of a particle is determined by the slope of its velocity-time graph.
conclusion: During the deceleration phases, for particle B, the deceleration phase occurs from 2v0 to 0 over 5t0. The slope of this segment is -2v0/5t0.

premise: The magnitude of acceleration is the absolute value of the slope.
conclusion: For particle A, the magnitude of acceleration during deceleration is 2v0/3t0.

premise: The magnitude of acceleration is the absolute value of the slope.
conclusion: For particle B, the magnitude of acceleration during deceleration is 2v0/5t0.

premise: The magnitudes of acceleration for A and B are 2v0/3t0 and 2v0/5t0 respectively.
conclusion: The ratio of the magnitudes of acceleration for A and B is (2v0/3t0) / (2v0/5t0) = 5/3.

premise: In a v-t graph, the slope represents acceleration. The red line represents the deceleration of A and B, and the ratio of their accelerations during this phase is equal to the ratio of the slopes.
conclusion: The ratio of the accelerations of A and B during deceleration is 1:1.
